nodes.text: Systematic comparison of typical feature selection methods for text classification can identify relative performance tradeoffs and provide a guideline to choose appropriate methods for academic and real-world TC tasks
High-dimensional text data contain many noisy terms that hurt text classification performance; feature selection reduces noisy terms and increases informative terms, improving classification accuracy
Few recent studies perform systematic performance comparisons covering many typical feature selection methods across varied text domains, creating a need for comprehensive benchmarking

We conducted comparison experiments on four benchmark datasets (CARR, COMD, IMDB, KDCN) using 20 typical feature selection methods and a decision tree classifier with 10-fold cross validation to assess classification accuracy under varying numbers of selected terms
The four datasets cover diverse domains (car reviews, business descriptions, movie reviews, Turkish news) and have prior use in published text mining tasks, supporting reliability of comparisons
Experimental results (DT accuracy vs number of selected terms) show MOR and MC-OR achieve the highest classification accuracies overall, with no significant difference between them; IGI ranks next
Unsupervised frequency-based methods TV, TVQ, TF, and DF obtain relatively good performance and provide a favorable efficiency-accuracy tradeoff; TVQ excels on IMDB
Information-theoretic and classic supervised filters IG, GI and MI achieve the worst classification accuracies among compared methods; MI maximum version outperforms its average version
ECE performs well in many cases but performs poorly when selecting small numbers of terms (e.g., 20 or 50); AMGM, MM and MAD yield unstable performance across datasets

Because MOR and MC-OR formulas are relatively complex and supervised methods require class distribution computations, IGI is recommended as a practical alternative due to competitive performance and simpler implementation
When computational efficiency is the priority, unsupervised methods TV, TVQ, TF and DF are preferred choices under the premise of relatively high classification accuracy
Method selection for text classification should balance classification accuracy and computational efficiency; the paper provides practical guidance mapping methods to these tradeoffs
